description: From Old French suburbe, subburbe, from Latin suburbium, from sub- + urbs (“city”). Displaced native Old English underburg, literally “sub-” or “under-city.”

entries.meaning: A residential area located on the outskirts of a city or large town that usually includes businesses that cater to its residents; such as schools, grocery stores, shopping centers, restaurants, convenience stores, etc.
(by extension) The outer part; the environment.
(Australia, New Zealand) Any subdivision of a conurbation, not necessarily on the periphery.
